page.title: 09Farming in the area
page.content: The land is very flat and until about 20 years ago when the River Roden was straightened and its' banks built up the land was very marshy. Occasionally the river still floods and because it is 3 metres above the land on either side it causes a lot of problems. Most farms are about 150 acres in size. North of the River Roden it is mainly arable and corn, suger beet and potatoes are grown. Mr. Lay is an arable farmer at the Ditches Farm. South of the River Roden it is mainly livestock farming.In this area, that means mostly cows, with some pigs and sheep. Mr. Stokes at Commonwood Farm is a livestock farmer.He has a herd of 120 friesians which he keeps for the milk.The calves are fattened for beef.Most of the milk goes to be made into cheese but a little is made into butter.
